Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in the 2017 Midwestern Graph Theory Conference held at Grand Valley State University in Allendale, Michigan, on October 6-7, 2017. The meeting is the 58th in a longstanding series of conferences dedicated to the dissemination of new ideas and techniques in graph theory and its applications. The conferences are held nearly every year at various institutions located in the Midwest and the surrounding regions. Attendees, including undergraduates as well as graduate students and post-doctoral scholars, are drawn from across the country.

This conference features plenary research talks by two well-known graph theorists, as well as contributed talks on a variety of topics such as graph coloring, structural and extremal problems on graphs and hypergraphs, and applications of graph theory (e.g., to computer science, biological and social networks, etc.). The entirety of the funds from this award will be used to support the travel of participants, including students and early-career mathematicians. More information about the conference is available at the conference website: http://www.gvsu.edu/math/mighty-lviii/

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 58th Midwestern Graph Theory Conference (MIGHTY LVIII) was held at Grand Valley State University in Allendale, MI from October 6-7, 2017.  The conference was sponsored by the National Science Foundation and by Grand Valley State University.  This generous support aided in attracting over 90 participants, with the NSF Grant used to support the travel of 33 graduate students and early career faculty.  Based on demographic information volunteered by 72 of the participants, 21 identified themselves as female, and 28 identified themselves with an underrepresented and/or minority group such as disabled, first-generation college student, immigrant to the U.S., LGBTQ, non-native English speaker, and religious minority.

The goals of this particular conference were to provide an atmosphere that encourages the dissemination of new results along with collaboration on future ones, to support the development of students (especially undergraduates) and early-career mathematicians, and to encourage and support the increase in diversity of researchers and participants in STEM.

The conference featured Douglas West (Zhejiang Normal University and University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign) and David Galvin (University of Notre Dame) as the two plenary speakers.  On Friday afternoon, David Galvin gave an additional talk specifically intended for an undergraduate audience.  A poster session followed this talk with 9 different posters presented by undergraduates from 5 different universities. 

In addition to the two plenary talks on Saturday, which were recorded and posted to the GVSU Math Youtube Channel (see https://youtu.be/Q6J3qDgiX00 and https://youtu.be/p8k0A3v3I_g), the conference featured a total of 40 contributed talks from senior faculty, early-career mathematicians, graduate students, and even undergraduates. 

The conference website is available at https://www.gvsu.edu/math/mighty-lviii/
